questions.question: I am not used to …………….. alone.
questions.description: Be used to can be followed by nouns or ing forms. It cannot be followed by infinitives.

questions.question: It took me quite some time to ……………… living in a big city.
I ……………… very hard last month.
questions.description: We do not use ‘used to’ to simply say what happened at a past time. That idea is expressed using the simple past.

questions.question: A minibus can hold ……………….. fifteen people.
questions.description: We use until to talk about time. To talk about quantity and distance, we use up to.

questions.question: Can you repair my camera if I leave it ……………… Friday?
questions.description: We use until to talk about a situation that will continue up to a certain moment. By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment.

questions.question: Can I stay with you ……………. Monday?
questions.description: We use until to talk about a situation that will continue up to a certain moment. By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment. Up to is used to indicate distance and quantity.

questions.question: You have to leave …………….. Tuesday midday at the latest.
questions.description: By is used to say that an action will happen at or before a future moment.

questions.question: The nearest restaurant is about half a kilometer …………….. the road.
questions.description: In this case both up and down can be used to mean ‘along’ with no difference of meaning.

questions.question: One cannot help ……………….. his courage.
questions.description: 'Cannot help but + infinitive' can be used with the meaning of ‘can’t help…ing’

questions.question: ……………… I become a billionaire, I will always lead a simple life.
questions.description: Even if refers to the future. Even though refers to the past. Even cannot be used as a conjunction.

questions.question: The man ………………. she married was an old friend of mine.
I have been working …………….. morning and I am getting tired.
questions.description: Since is normal with perfect and perfect continuous tenses.
